required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Measuring Skin Electrical Potential With the Kelvin Probe: Minimizing Noise
clinical_study.official_title: Measuring Skin Electrical Potential With the Kelvin Probe: Minimizing Noise

brief_summary.textblock: The Scanning Kelvin Probe measures surface electrical potential without actually touching the skin. This is a pilot study to evaluate methods of minimizing noise during Scanning Kelvin Probe measurements. This project will focus specifically on noise arising from physical movement and environmental electrical field.

primary_outcome.measure: Variability in surface electrical potential measurements
primary_outcome.description: This study focuses on the ability of the Kelvin Probe to measure skin electrical potential. Because it does so without touching the skin, it is prone to noise - specifically physical movement and surrounding electrical noise. The variability in surface electrical potential is a way to determine how stable the measurements are. It can be determined immediately after testing - and will be used in data analyses (comparing across study volunteers) approximately 24 weeks after testing is complete.

intervention.description: The Faraday cage is a copper-mesh cage that surrounds the device and test site. It helps eliminate surrounding electrical noise. Movement stabilization will be achieved by placing a velcro strap over the arm to minimize random movements.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age greater than 18 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- chronic medical condition requiring daily medications (hypertension, diabetes, hypothyroidism, etc)
- movement disorders/tremors
- extensive scars on the hand
- latex-allergies
- cardiac implantation, metallic joint/bone replacements (defibrillator or pacemaker)
